title: Walter Pattisson
text:
Walter Badeley Pattisson (27 August 1854 – 6 November 1913) was an English amateur <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er who played in 13 <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> matches between 1876 and 1887, primarily for <a href="Kent%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Kent County Cricket Club</a>. Pattisson sometimes played under the name W Batt.
Pattisson was born at <a href="Witham">Witham</a> in <a href="Essex">Essex</a> in 1854, one of the 16 children of solicitor Jacob Howell Pattisson and his wife Charlotte. He was educated at <a href="Tonbridge%20School">Tonbridge School</a> from the age of nine and played cricket for the school team as a <a href="wicket-keeper">wicket-keeper</a> for three years between 1869 and 1871, captaining the side in his final year at school. He made his first-class cricket debut for Kent in July 1876 in a match against <a href="Sussex%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Sussex County Cricket Club</a> at <a href="County%20Ground%2C%20Hove">Hove</a>. He played occasionally for the county club when his work as a solicitor allowed, making a total of 12 appearances for the county First XI and one for the amateur <a href="Gentlemen%20of%20Kent">Gentlemen of Kent</a> side.
As well as playing cricket, Pattisson played <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> and athletics. He played for <a href="Gipsies%20Football%20Club">Gipsies Football Club</a>, a rugby club formed by ex-Tonbridge men, appeared in rugby international trial matches between 1874 and 1876 and represented England in the <a href="hammer%20throw">hammer throw</a> against Ireland in 1877. He played club cricket for Tonbridge Cricket Club and Bickley Park and was secretary of both clubs as well as being a member of the Committee at Kent after he retired from playing and of the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20Union">Rugby Football Union</a> from 1878 to 1880.
Professional Pattisson became a senior partner in the legal firm Hores, Pattisson, and Bathurst and was a director of <a href="Legal%20%26amp%3B%20General">Legal & General</a> Life Assurance. He died at <a href="Beckenham">Beckenham</a> in <a href="Kent">Kent</a> in November 1913 aged 59. He was the President of the Old Tonbridgians Society at the time of his death and a pavilion was built on the school playing fields in his memory.
